conclusion: Four identical wooden blocks (A, B, C, D) are on a smooth horizontal surface. Blocks B and C are connected by a light spring (always within elastic limit). A horizontal pulling force F is applied to block B. All blocks accelerate together with the same acceleration.
Force F = ma is applied on block B, and there's also a force f = ma acting on block D.
Each block has mass m. All blocks have the same acceleration a. The surface is smooth (frictionless) except for the static friction between blocks.

premise: Block B has applied force F pulling to the right and spring force pulling to the left.
conclusion: F = ma (where a is the acceleration of the system).

premise: Block A must have some force causing it to accelerate with the same acceleration a. No external force is applied to A.
conclusion: There must be a static friction force from B pushing A forward, equal to ma.

premise: Block C is pulled to the right by the spring connected to B and must also push block D with static friction.
conclusion: Block D has a force f = ma acting on it to the left, representing the static friction force between block D and the external environment.

premise: The total force on the system must equal the total mass times acceleration: F = (4m)a. Force F = ma is applied to block B.
conclusion: The system acceleration would be a = F/(4m) = ma/(4m) = a/4.

premise: Force F = ma is applied to block B. Force f = ma is shown acting on block D to the left.
conclusion: The static friction force on block D equals ma in magnitude, directed to the left.

premise: The static friction force on block D equals ma in magnitude.
conclusion: The magnitude of the static friction force acting on block D during the acceleration process is ma.
